DataElement.preferredName: Excision Colorectal Pathology Mesorectum Intact Characteristic IntactnessOfMesorectum
DataElement.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the upper portion of the rectum and connecting it with the sacrum.:Undamaged in any way; whole.:The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance._Describes whether the mesorectum is intact after the sample is resected

DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination._The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the upper portion of the rectum and connecting it with the sacrum.:Undamaged in any way; whole.:The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: The act of cutting out; the surgical removal of part or all of a structure or organ.:Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.:The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Concepts.definition: The surgical removal of a lesion, often as part of a biopsy and with healthy margins.
Relating to the colon and rectum, or to the entire large bowel.

The medical science, and specialty practice, concerned with all aspects of disease, but with special reference to the essential nature, causes, and development of abnormal conditions, as well as the structural and functional changes that result from the disease processes. Informally used to mean the result of such an examination.

Property.preferredDefinition: The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the upper portion of the rectum and connecting it with the sacrum.:Undamaged in any way; whole.:The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

Concepts.definition: The fold of peritoneum, or mesentery, attached to the upper portion of the rectum and connecting it with the sacrum.
The distinguishing qualities or prominent aspect of a person, object, action, process, or substance.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Not whole; lacking some necessary part or detail; unfinished.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: To possess every necessary or normal part or component or step; having come or been brought to a conclusion.:Not far distant in time or space or degree or circumstances.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: Complete; having every necessary or normal part or component or step; or having come or been brought to a conclusion.
